qas.question: What is the rate that is used in most of the evidence?
What is more variable than spirometry but not recommended?
What is not as stable as prednisone for a routine diagnosis?

plausible_answers.text: for checking the effectiveness of new medications

qas.question: What is one instance when testing with prednisone is useful?

plausible_answers.text: in guiding treatment in those with acute exacerbations

qas.question: When may prednisone also be helpful in spirometry?
What percentage of a group think prednisone is helpful for treatment in acute cases?
What percentage of people in acute cases use salbutamol?

context: Other supportive evidence includes: a <a0_0>≥<b5_0>20%<b5_0/><a0_0/> difference in peak expiratory flow rate on at least three days in a week for at least two weeks, a ≥20% improvement of peak flow following treatment with either salbutamol, inhaled corticosteroids or prednisone, or a ≥<b6_0>20%<b6_0/> decrease in peak flow following exposure to a trigger<a1_0>. <b2_0>Testing peak expiratory flow<b2_0/><a1_0/> is more variable than spirometry, however, and thus not recommended for routine diagnosis. It may be useful for daily self-monitoring in those with moderate to severe disease and <b3_0>for checking the effectiveness of new medications<b3_0/>. It may also be helpful <b4_0>in guiding treatment in those with acute exacerbations<b4_0/>.
